poem:
**The Economics of Sound**

A gift,  
wrapped in wires—  
two small shells of sound.  

They sing of joy  
until silence creeps in—  
one mute pair,  
a lone whisperer.  

Is the price of repair  
worth its weight in song,  
or merely a discordant note  
in the commerce  
we're bound to hear?
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "I want my faulty earbud fixed. Should it cost less than replacing the pair? I have a pair of Beats earbuds I received as a Christmas gift three years ago. They have been replaced once for free by Apple when they developed a sound issue within the warranty period. Recently, one earbud stopped working. I went to an authorised Apple repairer and was told the price of fixing them was equivalent to buying a new". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
